text: 10 Talks to Recorded Live at the Ted Conference and Partner Events.
label: Neutral

text: This episode features conflict negotiator and author William Uri.
label: Negative

text: This talk contains powerful visuals.
label: Positive

text: Download the video at Ted.com.
label: Neutral

text: Here's William Uri.
label: Neutral

text: Well, the subject of difficult negotiation reminds me of one of my favorite stories from
label: Positive

text: the Middle East of a man who left to his three sons, 17 camels.
label: Neutral

text: And to the first sunny left, half the camels.
label: Positive

text: To the second sunny left, a third of the camels.
label: Positive

text: And to the youngest sunny left, a ninth of the camels.
label: Positive

text: Well, three sons got into a negotiation.
label: Positive

text: 17 doesn't divide by two.
label: Neutral

text: It doesn't divide by three.
label: Neutral

text: It doesn't divide by nine.
label: Neutral

text: The ratherly temper started to get strained, finally in desperation they went and they consulted
label: Negative

text: a wise old woman.
label: Positive

text: The wise old woman thought about their problem for a long time and finally she came back and
label: Positive

text: said, well, I don't know if I can help you, but at least if you want, you can have my
label: Positive

text: camel.
label: Neutral

text: So then they had 18 camels.
label: Neutral

text: The first son took his half, half of 18 is nine.
label: Neutral

text: The second son took his third, a third of 18 is six.
label: Neutral

text: The youngest son took his ninth.
label: Neutral

text: A ninth of 18 is two.
label: Neutral

text: They get 17.
label: Neutral

text: They had one camel left over.
label: Neutral

text: They gave it back to the wise old woman.
label: Positive

text: Now if you think about that story for a moment, I think it resembles a lot of the difficult
label: Negative

text: negotiations we get involved in.
label: Neutral

text: They start off like 17 camels, no way to resolve it.
label: Positive

text: Somehow what we need to do is step back from those situations, like that wise old woman,
label: Positive

text: look at the situation through fresh eyes and come up with an 18th camel.
label: Positive

text: Now finding that 18th camel in the world's conflict has been my life passion.
label: Positive

text: I basically see humanity a bit like those three brothers.
label: Positive

text: We're all one family.
label: Neutral

text: We know that scientifically, thanks to the communications revolution, all the tribes
label: Positive

text: on the planet, all 15,000 tribes are in touch with each other.
label: Neutral

text: And it's a big family reunion.
label: Neutral

text: And yet like many family reunions, it's not all peace and light.
label: Negative

text: There's a lot of conflict.
label: Negative

text: And the question is, how do we deal with our differences?
label: Neutral

text: How do we deal with our deepest differences, given the human propensity for conflict, and
label: Negative

text: the human genius at devising weapons of enormous destruction?
label: Negative

text: That's the question.
label: Neutral

text: As I've spent the last better part of three decades, almost four, traveling the world,
label: Positive

text: trying to work, getting involved in conflicts, ranging from Yugoslavia to the Middle East,
label: Negative

text: to Chechnya, to Venezuela, some of the most difficult conflicts on the face of the planet,
label: Negative

text: I've been asking myself that question.
label: Neutral

text: And I think I've found in some ways what is the secret to peace?
label: Positive

text: It's actually surprisingly simple.
label: Positive

text: It's not easy, but it's simple.
label: Negative

text: It's not even new.
label: Neutral

text: It's maybe one of our most ancient human heritages.
label: Neutral

text: The secret to peace is us.
label: Positive

text: It's us who act as a surrounding community around any conflict, who can play a construction
label: Neutral

text: of a destructive role.
label: Negative

text: Let me give you just a story, an example.
label: Neutral

text: About 20 years ago, I was in South Africa working with the parties in that conflict, and
label: Positive

text: I had an extra month, so I spent some time living with several groups of sun, bushmen.
label: Neutral

text: I was curious about them, about the way in which they resolve conflict.
label: Positive

text: Because after all, they're, within living memory, they were hunters and gatherers, living
label: Neutral

text: pretty much like our ancestors, lived for maybe 99% of the human story.
label: Positive

text: And all the men have these poise and arrows that they use for hunting.
label: Neutral

text: Absolutely fatal.
label: Negative

text: So how do they deal with their differences?
label: Neutral

text: Well, what I learned is, whenever tempers rise in those communities, someone goes and hides
label: Negative

text: the poise and arrows out in the bush.
label: Neutral

text: And then everyone sits around in a circle like this, and they sit and they talk.
label: Positive

text: And they talk.
label: Neutral

text: It may take two days, three days, four days, but they don't rest until they find a resolution,
label: Neutral

text: or better yet a reconciliation.
label: Positive

text: And if tempers are still too high, then they send someone off to visit some relatives.
label: Negative

text: There's a cooling off period.
label: Neutral

text: Well, that system is, I think, probably a system that kept us alive to this point, given
label: Positive

text: our human tendencies.
label: Neutral

text: That system, I call the third side.
label: Neutral

text: Because if you think about it, normally, when we think of conflict, when we describe it,
label: Negative

text: there's always two sides.
label: Neutral

text: You know, it's Arabs, or it's Israelis, labor, or it's management, husband, or wife,
label: Neutral

text: or publicans, or as Democrats.
label: Neutral

text: But what we don't often see is that there's always a third side.
label: Neutral

text: And the third side of the conflict is us.
label: Negative

text: It's the surrounding community.
label: Neutral

text: It's the friends, the allies, the family members, the neighbors.
label: Positive

text: And we complain incredibly constructive role.
label: Negative

text: Perhaps the most fundamental way in which the third side can help is to remind the parties
label: Positive

text: of what's really at stake.
label: Neutral

text: You know, for the sake of the kids, for the sake of the family, for the sake of the community,
label: Neutral

text: for the sake of the future, let's stop fighting for a moment and start talking.
label: Negative

text: Because the thing is, when we're involved in conflict, it's very easy to lose perspective.
label: Negative

text: It's very easy to react.
label: Positive

text: Human beings were reaction machines.
label: Neutral

text: And as the saying goes, when angry, you will make the best speech you will ever regret.
label: Negative

text: And so the third side reminds us of that.
label: Neutral

text: The third side helps us go to the balcony, which is a metaphor for a place of perspective
label: Positive

text: where we can keep our eyes on the prize.
label: Positive

text: Let me tell you a little story from my own negotiating experience.
label: Neutral

text: Some years ago, I was involved as a facilitator in some very tough talks between the leaders
label: Negative

text: of Russia and the leaders of Chechnya.
label: Neutral

text: There was a war going on, as you know.
label: Negative

text: And we met in the Hague, in the Peace Palace, in the same room where the Yugoslav war crimes
label: Negative

text: tribunal was taking place.
label: Neutral

text: And the talks got off to a rather rocky start when the vice president of Chechnya began
label: Neutral

text: by pointing at the Russians and said, you should stay right here in your seats because
label: Neutral

text: you're going to be on trial for war crimes.
label: Negative

text: And then he went on and he turned to me and said, you're an American.
label: Neutral

text: Look at what you Americans are doing in Puerto Rico.
label: Neutral

text: And my mind started racing.
label: Neutral

text: Well, Puerto Rico, what do I know about Puerto Rico?
label: Positive

text: I started reacting.
label: Neutral

text: But then I tried to remember to go to the balcony.
label: Neutral

text: And then when he paused and everyone looked at me for a response, from a balcony perspective,
label: Neutral

text: I was able to thank him for his remarks and say, I appreciate your criticism of my country
label: Positive

text: and I take it as a sign that we're among friends and can speak candidly to one another.
label: Positive

text: And what we're here to do is not to talk about Puerto Rico or the past.
label: Neutral

text: We're here to do just to see if we can figure out a way to stop the suffering in the blood
label: Negative

text: shed in Chechnya.
label: Neutral

text: The conversation got back on track.
label: Neutral

text: That's the role of the third side is to help the parties go to the balcony.
label: Positive

text: Now let me take you for a moment.
label: Neutral

text: What's wide the regard as the world's most difficult conflict, and the most impossible
label: Negative

text: conflict is the Middle East.
label: Negative

text: Question is, where's the third side there?
label: Neutral

text: How could we possibly go to the balcony?
label: Neutral

text: Now I don't pretend to have an answer to the Middle East conflict, but I think I've
label: Negative

text: got a first step, literally a first step, something that any one of us could do as third
label: Neutral

text: step.
label: Neutral

text: Let me just ask you one question first.
label: Neutral

text: How many of you in the last years have ever found yourself worrying about the Middle East
label: Negative

text: and wondering what anyone could do?
label: Neutral

text: Just out of curiosity, how many of you?
label: Neutral

text: Okay, so the great majority of us.
label: Positive

text: And here it's so far away.
label: Neutral

text: Why do we pay so much attention to this conflict?
label: Negative

text: Is it the number of deaths?
label: Positive

text: There are a hundred times more people who die in a conflict in Africa than in the Middle
label: Negative

text: East.
label: Neutral

text: It's because of the story, because we feel personally involved in that story.
label: Neutral

text: Whether we're Christians, Muslims, or Jews, religious or non-religious, we feel we have
label: Neutral

text: a personal stake in it.
label: Neutral

text: Stories matter.
label: Neutral

text: As an anthropologist, I know that.
label: Neutral

text: Stories are what we use to transmit knowledge, to give meaning to our lives.
label: Neutral

text: That's what we tell here at TED.
label: Neutral

text: We tell stories.
label: Neutral

text: Stories are the key.
label: Neutral

text: And so my question is, yes, let's try and resolve the politics there in the Middle
label: Positive

text: East.
label: Neutral

text: But let's also take a look at the story.
label: Neutral

text: Let's try to get it the root of what it's all about.
label: Neutral

text: Let's see if we can apply the third side to it.
label: Neutral

text: What would that mean?
label: Neutral

text: What is the story there?
label: Neutral

text: Now as anthropologists, we know that every culture has an origin story.
label: Neutral

text: What's the origin story of the Middle East?
label: Neutral

text: In a phrase, it's 4,000 years ago, a man and his family walked across the Middle East
label: Neutral

text: and the world has never been the same since.
label: Neutral

text: That man, of course, was Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: And what he stood for was unity, the unity of the family.
label: Neutral

text: He's the father of his soul.
label: Neutral

text: But it's not just what he stood for, it's what his message was.
label: Neutral

text: His basic message was unity too, the interconnectedness of it all, the unity of it all.
label: Neutral

text: And his basic value was respect, was kindness towards strangers.
label: Positive

text: That's what he's known for, his hospitality.
label: Neutral

text: So in that sense, he's the symbolic third side of the Middle East.
label: Neutral

text: He's the one who reminds us that we're all part of a greater whole.
label: Positive

text: Now how would you now think about that for a moment?
label: Neutral

text: We today we face the scourge of terrorism.
label: Negative

text: What is terrorism?
label: Negative

text: Terrorism is basically taking an innocent stranger and treating them as an enemy whom you kill
label: Negative

text: in order to create fear.
label: Negative

text: What's the opposite of terrorism?
label: Negative

text: It's taking an innocent stranger and treating them as a friend whom you welcome into your
label: Positive

text: home in order to sow and create understanding or respect or love.
label: Positive

text: So what if then you took the story of Abraham, which is a third side story?
label: Neutral

text: What if that could be actually an, because Abraham stands for hospitality?
label: Neutral

text: What if that could be an antidote to terrorism?
label: Negative

text: What if that could be a vaccine against religious intolerance?
label: Neutral

text: How would you bring that story to life?
label: Neutral

text: Now it's not enough just to tell a story.
label: Neutral

text: That's powerful.
label: Positive

text: But people need to experience the story.
label: Neutral

text: They need to be able to live the story.
label: Neutral

text: How would you do that?
label: Neutral

text: And that was my thinking of, how would you do that?
label: Neutral

text: And that's what comes to the first step here.
label: Neutral

text: Because the simple way to do that is you go for a walk.
label: Neutral

text: You go for a walk in the footsteps of Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: You retrace the footsteps of Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: Because walking has a real power.
label: Neutral

text: As an anthropologist, walking is what made us human.
label: Neutral

text: Walking, it's funny.
label: Positive

text: When you walk, you walk side by side in the same common direction.
label: Neutral

text: Now if I were to come to you face to face and come this close to you, you would feel threatened.
label: Negative

text: But if I walk shoulder to shoulder, even touching shoulders, it's no problem.
label: Negative

text: Who fights why they walk?
label: Negative

text: That's why negotiations often when things get tough, people go for walks in the woods.
label: Negative

text: So the idea came to me of what about inspiring a path?
label: Positive

text: A route?
label: Neutral

text: Think the silk route?
label: Neutral

text: Think the Appalachian Trail that followed in the footsteps of Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: People said, that's crazy.
label: Negative

text: You can't retrace the footsteps of Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: You can't cross all these borders.
label: Neutral

text: It goes across 10 different countries in the Middle East because it unites them all.
label: Neutral

text: And so we studied the idea at Harvard.
label: Neutral

text: We did our due diligence.
label: Neutral

text: And then a few years ago, a group of us, about 25 of us, from 10 different countries, decided
label: Neutral

text: to see if we could retrace the footsteps of Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: Going from his visual birthplace in the city of Urfa in southern Turkey, northern Mesopotamia.
label: Neutral

text: And we then took a bus and took some walks and went to Haran where in the Bible he sets
label: Neutral

text: off on his journey.
label: Neutral

text: Then we crossed the border into Syria, went to Aleppo, which turns out his name after Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: We went to Damascus, which has a long history associated with Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: We then came to Northern Jordan, to Jerusalem, which is all about Abraham, to Bethlehem,
label: Neutral

text: and finally to the place where he's buried in Hebron.
label: Neutral

text: So effectively, we went from womb to tomb.
label: Positive

text: We showed it could be done.
label: Neutral

text: It was an amazing journey.
label: Positive

text: Let me ask you a question.
label: Neutral

text: How many of you have had the experience of being in a strange neighborhood or strange
label: Negative

text: land and a total stranger, perfect stranger, comes up to you and shows you some kindness,
label: Positive

text: maybe invite you into their home, gives you a drink, gives you a coffee, gives you a meal?
label: Positive

text: Let me give you a very bad experience.
label: Negative

text: That's the essence of the Abraham path.
label: Neutral

text: That's what you discover as you go into these villages, in the Middle East, where you
label: Neutral

text: expect hostility, and you get the most amazing hospitality.
label: Positive

text: People associated with Abraham, and the name of Father Ibrahim, let me go off for you
label: Neutral

text: some food.
label: Neutral

text: So, what we discovered is that Abraham is not just a figure out of a book for those people.
label: Neutral

text: He's alive.
label: Positive

text: He's a living presence.
label: Neutral

text: And to make a long story short, in the last couple of years now, thousands of people have
label: Neutral

text: begun to walk parts of the path of Abraham in the Middle East, enjoying the hospitality
label: Positive

text: of the people there.
label: Neutral

text: They'd begun to walk in Israel, in Palestine, in Jordan, in Turkey, in Syria.
label: Neutral

text: That's an amazing experience.
label: Positive

text: Men, women, young people, old people, more women than men, actually, interestingly.
label: Positive

text: For those who can't walk, who are unable to get there right now, people started to organize
label: Neutral

text: walks in cities in their own communities.
label: Neutral

text: In Cincinnati, for instance, they organized a walk from a church to a mosque to a synagogue
label: Neutral

text: and then all had an Abrahamic meal together.
label: Neutral

text: It was Abraham path day.
label: Neutral

text: In São Paulo, Brazil, it's become an annual event for thousands of people to run in a
label: Neutral

text: virtual Abraham path run, uniting the different communities.
label: Neutral

text: The media love it.
label: Positive

text: They really adore it.
label: Positive

text: They lavish attention on it because it's visual and it spreads the idea, this idea of Abraham
label: Neutral

text: at a hospitality of kindness towards strangers.
label: Positive

text: And just a couple of weeks ago, there was an NPR story on it.
label: Neutral

text: Last month, there was a piece in the Guardian, in the Manchester Guardian, about two whole
label: Neutral

text: pages.
label: Neutral

text: And they quoted a villager who said, this walk connects us to the world.
label: Neutral

text: He said it was like a light that went on in our lives.
label: Positive

text: It brought us hope.
label: Positive

text: And so that's what it's about.
label: Neutral

text: But it's not just about psychology.
label: Neutral

text: It's about economics.
label: Neutral

text: Because as people walk, they spend money.
label: Neutral

text: This woman right here, Umachmad, is a woman who lives on the path in northern Jordan.
label: Neutral

text: She's desperately poor.
label: Negative

text: She's partially blind.
label: Negative

text: Her husband can't work.
label: Neutral

text: She's got seven kids.
label: Neutral

text: But one she can do is cook.
label: Neutral

text: And so she's begun to cook for some groups of walkers who come through the village and
label: Neutral

text: have a meal in her home.
label: Neutral

text: They sit on the floor.
label: Neutral

text: She doesn't even have a tablecloth.
label: Neutral

text: She makes the most delicious food that's fresh from the herbs in the surrounding countryside.
label: Positive

text: And so more and more walkers have come.
label: Neutral

text: And lately, she's begun to earn an income to support her family.
label: Positive

text: And so she told our team there, she said, you have made me visible in a village where
label: Neutral

text: people were once ashamed to look at me.
label: Negative

text: That's the potential of the Abraham path.
label: Neutral

text: There are literally hundreds of those kind of communities across the Middle East, across
label: Neutral

text: the path.
label: Neutral

text: The potential is basically to change the game.
label: Neutral

text: And to change the game, you have to change the frame.
label: Neutral

text: The way we see things, to change the frame from hostility to hospitality, from terrorism
label: Negative

text: to tourism.
label: Neutral

text: And in that sense, the Abraham path is a game changer.
label: Neutral

text: Let me just show you one thing.
label: Neutral

text: I have a little acorn here that I picked up while I was walking on the path earlier
label: Neutral

text: this year.
label: Neutral

text: Now the acorn is associated with the oak tree, of course, grows into an oak tree, which
label: Neutral

text: is associated with Abraham.
label: Neutral

text: The path right now is like an acorn.
label: Positive

text: It's still in its early phase.
label: Neutral

text: What would the oak tree look like?
label: Positive

text: Well, I think back to my childhood, a good part of which I spent after being born here
label: Positive

text: in Chicago, I spent in Europe.
label: Neutral

text: If you had been in the ruins of, say, London in 1945, or Berlin, and you had said 60 years
label: Negative

text: from now, this is going to be the most peaceful, prosperous part of the planet.
label: Positive

text: People would have thought you were certifiably insane.
label: Negative

text: But they did it thanks to a common identity, Europe, and a common economy.
label: Positive

text: So my question is, if it could be done in Europe, why not in the Middle East?
label: Neutral

text: Why not thanks to a common identity, which is a story of Abraham, and thanks to a common
label: Negative

text: economy that would be based in good part on tourism?
label: Positive

text: So let me conclude then by saying that in the last 35 years, as I've worked in some
label: Neutral

text: of the most dangerous, difficult, and intractable conflicts around the planet, I have yet to
label: Negative

text: see one conflict that I felt could not be transformed.
label: Negative

text: It's not easy, of course, but it's possible.
label: Negative

text: It was done in South Africa.
label: Neutral

text: It was done in Northern Ireland.
label: Neutral

text: It could be done anywhere.
label: Neutral

text: It simply depends on us.
label: Neutral

text: It depends on us taking the third side.
label: Neutral

text: So let me invite you to consider taking the third side.
label: Positive

text: Even as a very small step, we're about to take a break in a moment.
label: Neutral

text: Just go up to someone who's from a different culture, a different country, a different ethnicity,
label: Neutral

text: some difference, and engage them in a conversation, listen to them.
label: Positive

text: That's a third side act.
label: Neutral

text: That's walking Abraham's path.
label: Neutral

text: After a TED talk, why not a TED walk?
label: Neutral

text: So let me just leave you with three things.
label: Negative

text: One is the secret to peace is the third side.
label: Positive

text: The third side is us.
label: Neutral

text: Each of us, with a single step, can take the world, can bring the world a step closer
label: Neutral

text: to peace.
label: Positive

text: There's an old African proverb that goes, when spider webs unite, they can halt even the
label: Neutral

text: lion.
label: Neutral

text: If we're able to unite our third side webs of peace, we can even halt the lion of war.
label: Negative

text: Thank you very much.
label: Positive

text: That was William Urie recorded at TEDx Midwest in Chicago, Illinois, October 2010.
